Ge nanoparticles uniformly immobilized on 3D interconnected porous graphene frameworks as anodes for high-performance lithium-ion batteries Yao Chen a Yuming Zou a Xiaoping Shen a ⁎ Jingxia Qiu a Jiabiao Lian a Jinrui Pu a Sheng Li a Fei-Hu Du b ⁎ Shang-Qi Li b Zhenyuan Ji a Aihua Yuan c a School of Material Science and Engineering, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Institute for Energy Research, Jiangsu University, Zhenjiang 212013, Jiangsu, China School of Material Science and Engineering School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Institute for Energy Research Jiangsu University Zhenjiang 212013 Jiangsu China School of Material Science and Engineering, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Institute for Energy Research, Jiangsu University, Zhenjiang 212013, Jiangsu, China b School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai University, Shanghai 200444, China School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering Shanghai University Shanghai 200444 China School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai University, Shanghai 200444, China c School of Environmental & Chemical Engineering, Jiangsu University of Science and Technology, Zhenjiang 212003, Jiangsu, China School of Environmental & Chemical Engineering Jiangsu University of Science and Technology Zhenjiang 212003 Jiangsu China School of Environmental & Chemical Engineering, Jiangsu University of Science and Technology, Zhenjiang 212003, Jiangsu, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The unique Ge/3DPG architecture with Ge nanoparticles tightly anchored on the 3D porous graphene skeleton boosts the surface-controlled kinetics and the reversible utilization of Li2O, resulting in a high lithium-storage capacity and superior rate capability. Germanium (Ge), an alloy-type anode material for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), possesses many advantages such as high theoretical capacity and decent electrical conductivity. Nevertheless, its application is restricted by tremendous volume variation and tardy reaction kinetic during discharge/charge process. In this paper, the Ge/3DPG composites with Ge nanoparticles uniformly dispersed in 3D interconnected porous graphene (3DPG) skeleton are successfully prepared using a template-assisted in-situ reduction method. The unique 3D interconnected porous graphene can not only enhance the electronic conductivity and reaction kinetics of the materials, but also provide sufficient buffer space to effectively mitigate the volume expansion during cycling and strengthen the structural integrity. Moreover, the small-sized Ge nanoparticles in close conjunction with the 3D graphene can boost the surface-controlled reaction of the electrode, which contributes to a fast charge–discharge rate capability. The Ge/3DPG composite with optimized Ge/graphene mass ratio delivers high reversible specific capacity (1102 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.2 C), outstanding rate capability (494 mAh g−1 at 5 C), and admirable cycling stability (85.3% of capacity retention after 250 cycles at 0.5 C). This work provides a significant inspiration for the design and fabrication of advanced Ge-based anode materials for next-generation high-performance LIBs. Keywords Germanium nanoparticles 3D porous graphene Composites Anode materials Lithium storage performance 1 Introduction With the increasing needs for portable electronic devices and large-scale hybrid electric vehicles, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have obtained lots of attention as an efficient energy storage device on account of their advantages of high energy density, environmental friendliness, and no-memory effect, etc. [1,2]. The electrochemical performance of batteries is closely correlative with the inherent properties of electrode materials, including theoretical capacities, electronic conductivity, and volumetric change during Li+ insertion/extraction. Lithium alloy anode materials, particularly group ⅣA elements of silicon and germanium, possess high theoretical capacities (4200 mAh g−1 for Si and 1600 mAh g−1 for Ge), and thus have been widely researched as promising anode candidates for LIBs. Compared with Si, the metallic Ge possesses better Li+ diffusivity (400 times more than Si) and higher electrical conductivity (104 times more than Si), which could endow Ge anode with superior rate capability and cycling stability. Nevertheless, Ge electrodes usually experience large volumetric expansion (over 200%) in the Li+ insertion/extraction process, which can cause the severe structural collapse and pulverization of the electrodes, and loss of electrical contact between electrode materials and current collector, thereby inducing a serious capacity fading [3]. To solve the above problem, various nanostructured Ge materials, including nanoparticles [4,5], nanowires [6,7], and nanotubes [8,9], have been designed and studied as anode materials for LIBs. It is because compared with their bulk counterparts, nanostructured materials not only possess larger specific surface areas beneficial to the electrode/electrolyte contact, but also shorten the distance of Li+ diffusion and electron transport to enhance the reaction kinetics. However, it is inevitable for low-dimensional Ge nanomaterials to increase side reactions due to their relatively large surface area, along with the inferior mechanical stability caused by the loose particle stacking, resulting in poor structural integrity and low capacity retention. Besides, a small amount of germanium oxide generated at the boundaries of Ge nanoparticles would cause the irreversible formation of Li2O during the first lithium insertion, which reduced the initial Coulomb efficiency [10–12]. Recently, combining nanosized Ge with carbon materials (e.g. graphene, carbon nanotubes, porous carbon, etc.) has been considered as an efficient way to improve the electrochemical performance of the Ge anodes [13–16]. Among multifarious carbon materials, three-dimensional (3D) graphene with 3D interconnected porous frameworks is extremely appealing because of its outstanding chemical and physical properties such as high electrical conductivity, excellent chemical stability, and interconnected porous structure with rich pore sizes [17,18]. Given the above advantages, confining nanosized Ge in 3D porous graphene would improve the electronic conductivity of electrode materials and provide a flexible space to alleviate the huge volume change of Ge during the charge–discharge process. Especially, the unique 3D interpenetrating structure can not only offer rich conductive pathways for Li+ diffusion and electron conduction, and fast reaction kinetic, but also can accelerate reversible utilization of Li2O, consequently delivering an enhanced lithium storage performance [12,19]. However, because of the great synthesis challenge, the composites with nanosized Ge anchored on 3D porous graphene frameworks have been rarely reported until now [20]. In this paper, we demonstrate a facile template-assisted method to synthesize Ge nanoparticles uniformly decorated 3D porous graphene (Ge/3DPG). Benefitted from the synergistic effect of nanosized Ge and 3D interconnected porous graphene, the as-prepared Ge/3DPG composite exhibits remarkably improved lithium storage performance in terms of the reversible specific capacity, rate capability, and long-term cycling stability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Germanium dioxide (GeO2, 99.99%), graphite powder (99.95%, 325 mesh), Tris(hydroxymethyl)aminomethane hydrochloride (Tris-HCl), and polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP, K30) were purchased from Aladdin Chemistry Co., Ltd. (China). Poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride) solution (PDDA, 35 wt% in water, M w < 100000) was purchased from Macklin Chemistry Co., Ltd. (China). All other chemical reagents are analytically pure and used as received without further purification. Graphite oxide was synthesized from graphite powder by modified Hummers’ method [21]. Graphene oxide (GO) suspension was obtained by ultrasonic exfoliation of 400 mg of graphite oxide in 200 mL of DI water. 2.2 Synthesis of PDDA-modified polystyrene nanospheres Polystyrene (PS) nanospheres were synthesized by an emulsifier-free emulsion polymerization method using styrene monomer as the precursor, polyvinyl pyrrolidone as the stabilizer, and ammonium persulfate as the initiator [22]. Briefly, 0.76 g of PVP was firstly added to 30 mL of deionized (DI) water under constant mechanical stirring and subsequently transferred to a 250 mL of three-neck flask. Secondly, after being purged with nitrogen for 15 min, 3.9 g of styrene monomer and 0.5 g of ammonium persulfate were added to the above solution, and then the obtained mixture was heated at 70 ℃ for 8 h. After cooling, the as-synthesized PS nanospheres were collected by filtration and washed with methanol several times. Finally, 0.2 g of the as-synthesized PS nanospheres were dispersed in the mixed solution of PDDA (2.133 g), sodium chloride (0.173 g), and Tris-HCl (0.363 g)) under a vigorous stirring overnight. The PDDA-modified PS nanospheres (PDDA-PS) were collected by centrifugation, washed with DI water several times, and followed by freeze-drying. 2.3 Fabrication of Ge/3DPG composites The Ge/3DPG composites were prepared using PS nanospheres as a sacrificial template. Firstly, 0.04 g of the PDDA-PS nanospheres was dispersed in 40 mL of DI water by sonication, forming a homogeneous milk-white suspension. Meanwhile, GeO2 (2.0 mmol, 0.21 g) was dissolved in 8 mL of 0.15 M NaOH aqueous solution containing 0.02 g of PVP with continuous stirring for 0.5 h, and then the resultant Na2GeO3 aqueous solution was dropwise added into the above PDDA-PS suspension and stirred for 6 h. After adjusting the pH value of the mixture to 7 with 0.5 M HCl solution, it was added into 30 mL of GO suspension, followed by stirring overnight. The resulted mixture was added into 8 mL of 0.32 M NaBH4 solution in an ice bath, and then was kept at 60 ℃ for 3 h. The product of amorphous PS@Ge/RGO was washed thoroughly with DI water via repeating centrifugation-decantation processes, and subjected to freeze drying for 24 h. For comparison, amorphous PS@Ge product was also synthesized according to the same procedure as described above but without adding GO suspension. The Ge/3DPG composite (denoted as Ge/3DPG-2) was obtained through annealing the as-prepared PS@Ge/RGO precursor at 650 ℃ for 6 h under an H2/Ar gas flow (containing 10 vol% H2) with a heating rate of 5 ℃ min−1. For comparison, the samples of Ge/3DPG-1 and Ge/3DPG-3 were also prepared according to the same procedure as described above, but the feeding amount of GeO2 was changed to 1.25 mmol (0.13 g) and 2.5 mmol (0.26 g), respectively. In addition, the sample of Ge was obtained through annealing the as-prepared PS@Ge under the same condition, marked as Ge-2 according to the GeO2 used amount of 2.0 mmol (0.21 g). 2.4 Materials characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were conducted on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE diffractometer with Cu-K α radiation source (λ = 1.5406 Å) to investigate the crystal structures of as-synthesized materials. The ζ-potential tests were carried out using a Zetasizer Nano ZS90 apparatus. Raman spectra were recorded on a JYHR800 Raman spectrometer with a 532 nm laser source. The carbon contents in the resultant composites were evaluated by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, NETZSCH STA449 C) in air atmosphere. To calculate the specific surface area and pore size distribution of the as-obtained materials, Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model were used, respectively, based on N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms that were determined on a surface area and porosity analyzer (NDVA-2000e). Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, JSM-7001F) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100) were conducted to characterize the morphology, size and microstructure of the resultant samples. Elemental mapping images were acquired on a Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin TEM. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed by using a Thermo ESCALAB 250XI system with an Al K α X-ray excitation source. To accomplish ex-situ XRD and SEM analyses, the electrodes were detached from the cycled cells at different charge/discharge states and washed with diethyl carbonate (DEC) to remove impurities and electrolyte salt, and eventually sealed in a vacuum packing bag to avoid long exposure to air and water. 2.5 Electrochemical measurements Two-electrode electrochemical tests were executed using CR2032 coin cells. To prepare the working electrodes, active materials (the as-prepared samples), the conductive agent (acetylene black) and the binder (carboxymethylcellulose sodium) with a weight ratio of 8:1:1 were thoroughly mixed in a certain amount of DI water to form a homogeneous slurry. Subsequently, the resultant slurry was uniformly coated onto pure copper foil (99.99%, Hefei KeJing Materials Technology Co., Ltd) and dried in a vacuum oven at 80 ℃ for 24 h, and finally cut into disks with a diameter of 12 mm as the working electrode. The coin-type cells were assembled in an Ar-filled glove box (O2 < 0.1 ppm, H2O < 0.1 ppm) with Celgard 2032-type polypropylene (PP) micro-porous film as the separator, and lithium foil as both reference and counter electrodes. In addition, 1.0 M LiPF6 in the mixed solvent of ethylene carbonate (EC)/diethyl carbonate (DEC) (1:1 by volume) and 5 wt% fluoride ethylene carbonate (FEC) was used as the electrolyte. Afterwards, the galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) measurements of the coin-type half cells were performed on a NEWARE-BTS-3008 battery test system with the potential range of 0.01–1.5 V versus Li+/Li. Cyclic voltammogram (CV) tests were carried out on CHI 760E electrochemical workstation (Shanghai Chenhua) in the voltage range of 0.01–1.5 V (vs. Li+/Li) at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) tests were performed on the above electrochemical workstation in the frequency range of 100 mHz to 100 kHz by applying an AC amplitude of 10 mV. All the measurements were carried out at room temperature, and the specific capacity values were calculated based on the entire weight of the samples. In addition, the lithium storage mechanism of Ge/3DPG-2 was studied by in-situ XRD (Bruker, D8 Advance). For the full Li-ion battery measurements, the Ge/3DPG-2 composite as an anode was paired with commercial LiFePO4 (LFP) cathode, and the capacity ratio of the negative electrode to positive electrode (N/P ratio) was controlled to be 1.05–1.10. The positive electrode was prepared by mixing 80 wt% of LiFePO4, 10 wt% of acetylene black and 10 wt% of polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP), and then the slurry was spread on an Al foil and dried in vacuum at 110 ℃ for 12 h. Before assembling the full battery, the Ge/3DPG-2 anode was pre-lithiated to reduce the initial irreversible capacity. The pre-lithiated procedure was completed by three cycles of discharging-charging at the current density of 800 mA g−1 in the voltage range of 0.01–1.5 V, with a lithium metal foil as the reference/counter electrodes. The voltage window of the as-prepared full batteries was set at 1.5–3.7 V [15]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization The Ge/3DPG composites were synthesized with polystyrene (PS) nanospheres as a sacrificial template and GeO2 as a low-cost Ge source instead of the traditional expensive reagents of germanium halides (GeI4, GeI2, GeCl4) and germanium ethoxide (C8H20GeO4) [3,23,24]. Fig. 1 intuitively illustrates the synthetic route of the Ge/3DPG composites, mainly comprising three steps as follows: i) The surface of PS nanospheres is first functionalized by the cationic polymer PDDA to load abundant positive charges, denoted as PDDA-PS. The zeta potential of the resulted PDDA-PS is 36.2 mV, while that of PS nanospheres is −29.6 mV, confirming that the surface of PDDA-PS becomes electropositive due to the modification of PDDA. ii) Negatively charged GeO3 2- ions and GO sheets were adsorbed and assembled on the surface of PDDA-PS spheres via electrostatic interaction, followed by in-situ reduction with NaBH4 as reducing agent to obtain the amorphous PS@Ge/RGO composites. iii) The amorphous PS@Ge/RGO composites were annealed under an H2/Ar atmosphere to improve the crystallinity of Ge and the graphitization degree of RGO. Meanwhile, the PS spheres were decomposed during the annealing process, leaving some hollow cavities in the materials. As a result, the Ge/3DPG composites with Ge nanocrystals uniformly immobilized on 3D interconnected porous graphene framework were successfully obtained. Obviously, the uniform PS nanospheres as a template play an important role in the construction of the Ge/3DPG composites. Further, in the above synthesis process, the surfactant poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP) serves as a dispersing agent to effectively facilitate the dispersion and nucleation of germanium on the surface of the PS template, and together with GO sheets well prevent germanium nanoparticles from aggregating. The microstructure and morphology of the resultant samples were characterized by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). As shown in Fig. S1(a), the as-synthesized PS nanospheres are highly homogeneous with a diameter of ca. 130 nm. After being modified by the cationic polyelectrolyte of PDDA, the dispersity of the nanospheres was evidently improved (Fig. S1b). For the PS@Ge sample, the surface of the nanospheres became rougher, and the diameter increased to ca. 165 nm, owing to the anchoring of Ge nanoparticles on the surface of PS spheres (Fig. S1c). In contrast, sheet-like products, instead of the nanospheres, were mainly observed in the PS@Ge/RGO composite because the PS@Ge nanospheres were well wrapped by RGO sheets (Fig. 2 a). After the removal of PS nanospheres by the thermal treatment, the resultant Ge/3DPG-2 composite shows a 3D graphene framework structure with numerous well-interconnected pores (Fig. 2b). The unique 3D interconnected porous structure can be further verified by TEM. As shown in Fig. 2(c-g), the 3D graphene was homogeneously decorated by uniform spherical cavities with a diameter of ca. 135 nm, which is well consistent with the size of PS nanospheres modified by PDDA, implying that the spherical cavities were formed by the PS template during the annealing process. It can be seen that the wall of the spherical cavities consists of RGO sheets and tiny Ge nanoparticles (ca. 25 nm) (Fig. 2f and g). As illustrated in Fig. 2(h), the high resolution (HR) TEM image displays clear lattice fringes with a spacing of 0.33 nm, which matches well with the (111) plane of diamond cubic Ge, demonstrating the formation of Ge nanoparticles in the Ge/3DPG-2 product [15]. The energy dispersive spectrum (EDS) confirms the existence of Ge, C and O elements in the composite (Fig. S3). High-angle annular dark field (HAADF) scanning TEM (STEM) image (Fig. 2i) and the corresponding elemental mapping images (Fig. 2i) of Ge/3DPG-2 unveil the uniform distribution of the C, Ge and O elements, indicating that the composite possesses uniform texture. The O element may come from RGO as well as the surface oxidation of the Ge nanoparticles. For the single Ge-2 product, owing to without RGO protection, most Ge particles show much larger size (ca. 720 nm) and severe aggregation (Fig. S2). The crystalline structures of as-prepared materials were studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD). Before annealing, the PS@Ge/RGO-2 composite displays only two broad diffraction peaks originating from RGO, revealing the amorphous characteristic of Ge in the composite (Fig. S4). After annealing, the resulted Ge/3DPG-2 exhibits several intense diffraction peaks (Fig. 3 a), which can be well indexed to the diamond cubic Ge (JCPDS No. 04–0545) [24]. Similar XRD patterns can also be observed in Ge-2, Ge/3DPG-1 and Ge/3DPG-3 (Fig. 3a), indicating that the crystallinity of Ge can be remarkably improved by the annealing process. It is noteworthy that the diffraction peaks related to RGO are not evident in the XRD patterns of the Ge/3DPG composites, probably because of the relatively low crystallinity of RGO compared to Ge. The existence of RGO can be proved by Raman spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 3(b), Raman spectra of the as-synthesized Ge/3DPG composites present two broad peaks at ca. 1342 and 1592 cm−1, which correspond to the D-band and G-band of carbonaceous materials, respectively, revealing the presence of RGO [25]. The D-band arises from a breathing mode of k-point phonons of A 1g symmetry while the G-band corresponds to the first order scattering of the E 2g phonons of sp 2 C atoms [26,27]. The intensity ratios (I D/I G) are usually utilized to assess the graphitization degree and the structural defects of carbon materials. The intensity ratios (I D/I G) of the as-prepared samples were calculated according to the integral area of the D and G peaks [28], and they are 1.73 (Ge/3DPG-1), 1.82 (Ge/3DPG-2), and 2.24 (Ge/3DPG-3), respectively, which are higher than that of GO (1.36). The increased I D/I G values are attributed to the formation of new and smaller sp 2 domains during the reduction, further implying the successful reduction of GO into RGO in the Ge/3DPG composites [29,30]. Moreover, the I D/I G ratios of the obtained Ge/3DPG samples show a gradual increase with the increasing Ge content, which is because the attachment of Ge particles on graphene sheets can stress its surface and induce more defects [30]. The carbon contents of as-synthesized composites were evaluated by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). As shown in Fig. 3(c), there are two obvious weight losses in the temperature range of 25 to 540 ℃, in which the weight loss below 200 ℃ is mainly relevant to the loss of the absorbed water, while the weight loss at 200–540 ℃ is due to the oxidation removal of RGO in air atmosphere. Subsequently, two slight weight gains occur at 540–900 ℃, which can be attributed to the oxidation of Ge to GeO2. Based on the above TGA results, the Ge contents in Ge/3DPG-1, Ge/3DPG-2 and Ge/3DPG-3 can be determined to be about 47.6 wt%, 49.9 wt% and 59.6 wt%, respectively [15]. Through deducting the absorbed water contents, the carbon contents were calculated to be approximately 50.5 wt%, 46.7 wt% and 37.3 wt% for Ge/3DPG-1, 2, 3, respectively. As shown in Fig. 3(d), the nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms of Ge/3DPG-2 feature an apparent hysteresis loop, belonging to a typical type-IV isotherm. The similar isotherms were also observed in Ge/3DPG-1 (Fig. S5a) and Ge/3DPG-3 (Fig. S5c). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas of as-synthesized composites are 127 m2 g−1 (Ge/3DPG-1), 119 m2 g−1 (Ge/3DPG-2) and 43 m2 g−1 (Ge/3DPG-3), which are remarkably higher than that of Ge-2 (18 m2 g−1) (Fig. 3e) due to the contribution of the 3D porous graphene framework. The corresponding pore-size distribution plots (Fig. 3f, S5b, S5d) clearly indicate the existence of mesopores in the as-prepared materials. Compared with Ge-2, the Ge/3D-PG composites with higher surface areas are conducive to enlarge the electrical contact area between the electrolyte and electrode materials, providing more active sites for Li+ storage. The surface elemental composition and chemical state of the as-prepared Ge/3DPG-2 were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and the results are shown in Fig. 3(g-i) and Fig. S6. The XPS survey (Fig. 3g) manifests the presence of C, Ge and O elements in the composite, which matches well with the elemental mapping and EDS results. As shown in Fig. 3(h), the high-resolution XPS spectrum at Ge 3d region can be fitted to three peaks located at 29.2, 29.9 and 31.8 eV, corresponding to Ge-Ge, Ge-C and Ge-O, respectively [31–33]. The weak Ge-O peak suggests the partial oxidation of Ge nanoparticles induced by high surface activity of the nanoscale Ge [34]. The Ge-C bond could be caused by the Ge atoms penetrating into the 3D graphene skeleton [34], in which the interfacial carbon atoms bonded with Ge during the annealing process, indicating there is a good combination between Ge nanoparticles and the 3D interconnected graphene frameworks to enhance the overall mechanical stability for bulk material [35]. The high-resolution C 1 s spectrum (Fig. 3i) can be deconvoluted into five peaks at 284.1, 284.6, 285.2, 286.4 and 288.9, which are relevant to C-Ge, C–C, C-O, C = O and O-C = O, respectively [36,37]. As shown in Fig. S6, the high-resolution O 1 s spectrum comprises three peaks of O-C (533.1 eV), O = C (531.9 eV) and O-Ge (531.0 eV), respectively. 3.2 Electrochemical performance The Li-storage performances of the as-obtained samples are investigated by cyclic voltammogram (CV), galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD), and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). Fig. 4 (a) shows CV curves of the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode for the initial three cycles at 0.1 mV s−1 in a potential window of 0.01–1.5 V. During the initial Li-insertion process, the CV curve shows a slight fluctuation at 0.75–0.60 V (the inset of Fig. 4a), which corresponds to the decomposition of electrolyte to form solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) film [23,38]. In addition, a broad cathodic peak occurs between 0.55 and 0.29 V, accompanied by a small peak at ca. 0.21 V, which may involve the following two lithiation processes: i) the electrochemical conversion of the native oxide at the Ge grain boundaries into Ge and Li2O; ii) the subsequent reversible alloying reaction of the Ge with Li to generate various amorphous Li x Ge (a-Li x Ge) phases [9,12,39]. Upon the further insertion of lithium, a sharp reduction peak is observed at ca. 0.05 V, indicative of the transformation of a-Li x Ge alloys to the crystalline Li15Ge4 (c-Li15Ge4) phase [3,40]. In the reverse process, there is a sharp oxidation peak located at ca. 0.56 V, accompanied by a weak broad peak at ca. 0.41 V, which is related to the de-alloying reaction of Li x Ge, especially, the anodic peak near ca. 0.56 V originates from the Li+ extraction from the fully lithiated c-Li15Ge4 phase [40,41]. Subsequently, a broad anodic peak associated with the re-oxidation of the amorphous Ge (a-Ge) appeared at ca. 1.12 V, indicative of the partially reversible conversion of Li2O/Ge to germanium oxide [42]. From the 2nd cycle onwards, the above cathodic peaks were replaced by a series of reduction peaks appearing at 0.01–0.75 V, which can be associated with the decomposition of the germanium oxide regenerated during the initial charging process as well as the consecutive lithiation of Ge to a series of Li-Ge phases, as previously reported in the literature [43]. This change is probably due to the decreasing size and the formation of an amorphous structure for active particles (Ge) after the initial discharge/charge, which are beneficial to shorten the pathway for Li+ transport and improve the phase transformation of a-Li x Ge to c-Li15Ge4 [40,44,45]. Interestingly, for the initial 3 cycles, the anodic peak associated with the de-lithiation of c-Li15Ge4 at ca. 0.56 V becomes more apparent, along with a slight increasing intensity of the de-alloying peak at about 0.41 V, further revealing a stepwise activated process accompanied by the formation of more of the high-capacity c-Li15Ge4 phase [40]. The aforesaid change together with the reversible conversion Li2O/Ge can to a great degree guarantee the high capacity and cycling stability of the electrode. The lithium storage capacities of the as-synthesized samples were systematically studied by galvanostatic charge/discharge tests in the potential window of 0.01–1.5 V. Fig. 4(b) shows the respective discharge/charge profiles of Ge, Ge/3DPG-1, Ge/3DPG-2, and Ge/3DPG-3 electrodes for the 1st cycle at the activated current density of 0.05C (1C = 1600 mA g−1). It can be seen that all of these electrodes have similar discharge and charge plateaus. For the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode, the initial discharge/charge specific capacities are 2034 and 1239 mAh g−1, respectively, with a low initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) of 61%. The low ICE can be ascribed to the generation of large SEI layer during the first discharging process due to the large surface area of the anode in direct contact with the electrolytes [46,47], which consumed a large amount of Li+ and resulted in irreversible lithium loss. The initial discharge/charge specific capacities and the corresponding ICE for Ge, Ge/3DPG-1 and Ge/3DPG-3 electrodes are listed in Table S1. Subsequently, the Coulombic efficiency (CE) of the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode dramatically increases to 98% at the 4th cycle, and reaches up to 99% at the 10th cycle. As shown in Fig. S7(a), from the 4th to 100th cycles, the GCD curves of Ge/3DPG-2 keep almost overlapping, indicating high capacity stability of the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode. In contrast, the CE value of the Ge-2 electrode approaches 95% after cycling four times, and slowly increases to 99% until the 50th cycle, accompanied by serious capacity degeneration during the cycling (Fig. S7b) [48]. After 100 cycles at the current density of 0.2C (Fig. 4c), the discharge specific capacities maintain at 719 mAh g−1 (Ge/3DPG-1), 1102 (Ge/3DPG-2) and 845 (Ge/3DPG-3), which are much higher than that of Ge-2 (465 mAh g−1). As displayed in Fig. 4(d), the rate performances of the Ge/3DPG-1, Ge/3DPG-2, Ge/3DPG-3, and Ge-2 electrodes were investigated at various current densities of 0.1–5 C for 10 cycles. Obviously, the rate capability increases gradually in the order of Ge, Ge/3DPG-1, Ge/3DPG-3 and Ge/3DPG-2 (Fig. S8). Impressively, the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode exhibits high reversible capacities of 1144, 1077, 1017, 952, 826, and 719 mAh g−1 at the current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, and 3 C, respectively. Even at a high rate of 5 C, Ge/3DPG-2 displays a remarkable reversible capacity of 494 mAh g−1, which is much larger than that of Ge (63 mAh g−1). The excellent rate capability is also validated by the discharge and charge profiles at different current densities (Fig. S9). When the current density goes back to 0.2C, the reversible capacity of the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode can recover to 1035 mAh g−1, indicative of its excellent rate performance. Thus, compared to the bare Ge electrode, the Ge/3DPG composite electrodes have higher specific capacities and better rate capability. It is because the introduction of the 3D interconnected porous graphene framework can effectively buffer the huge volume variation of the electrodes, and promote the diffusion/transport of lithium ions and electrons, resulting in the improved Li-storage performance of the Ge/3DPG electrodes. Furthermore, compared with Ge/3DPG-1 and Ge/3DPG-3, the Ge/3DPG-2 shows better Li-storage performance, possibly because the appropriate RGO content in Ge/3DPG-2 can not only make Ge nanoparticles well confined in the 3D porous graphene framework, which enhances its conductivity and structural integrity, but also avoid the low utilization of excessive Ge nanoparticles and blocking the open pores of the 3D graphene to improve the specific capacity of electrode materials [49]. Thus, it is also important to optimize the ratio of Ge to RGO to achieve superior lithium storage performance. The EIS feature of the Ge/3DPG-1, Ge/3DPG-2, Ge/3DPG-3 and Ge electrodes before and after cycling was also researched in the frequency range of 105-10-2 Hz. Fig. 4(e) displays the Nyquist plots before cycling, which consist of a semicircle in the high- middle-frequency zone and a slope in the low-frequency zone, respectively. The diameter of the semicircle is related with the charge transfer resistance of the electrode, and the latter represents the Warburg resistance induced by the Li+ diffusion in the solid phase. The Nyquist plots were fitted according to the equivalent circuit (the inset of Fig. 4e), in which R s stands for the internal resistance caused by the electrolyte and battery internal parts, and R ct is the charge transfer resistance. The corresponding fitting results are detailedly recorded in Table S2. It can be seen that the R ct values are 43.6 for Ge/3DPG-1, 80.9 for Ge/3DPG-2, and 113.0 Ω for Ge/3DPG-3, and they are much lower than the bare Ge electrode (169.0 Ω), demonstrating that the introduction of RGO can effectively improve the electronic conductivity. Meanwhile, as expected, the R ct values of the three composite electrodes reduce with the decrease of RGO content. The linear relationship of Z're - ω -1/2 in the low-frequency zone was subsequently utilized to investigate the Li+ diffusion behavior in the electrodes (Fig. 4f). The corresponding slope value can reflect the Li+-diffusion kinetics within the electrode. Compared to the bare Ge electrode, the three composite electrodes exhibit smaller slope values, indicative of their faster lithium ion diffusion [50,51]. The fast Li+ diffusion is conducive to enhancing the rate performance of the composite electrodes. Subsequently, the EIS analysis of the as-prepared electrodes after 100 cycles was carried out under the fully lithiated state, and the Nyquist plots are shown in Fig. S10(a). Fig. S10(b) shows the corresponding equivalent circuit, where R f represents the resistance relevant to the SEI film. As seen from the fitting results (Table S3), the R f values of the three composite electrodes are smaller than that of the Ge electrode, implying that the formation of stable and thin SEI film on the composite electrodes [52,53]. Meanwhile, after cycling for 100 times, the Ge/3DPG-1 (6.8 Ω), Ge/3DPG-2 (7.9 Ω), and Ge/3DPG-3 (10.2 Ω) electrodes still show lower Rct values than the Ge-2 electrode (20.2 Ω), revealing that the three composites maintain the enhanced electronic conductivity after the repeated cycling, which is well consistent with the above electrochemical performance test results. The long cyclic characteristics of the as-obtained electrodes were also investigated at a relatively high rate of 0.5C (for the 1st cycle with an activated current density of 0.05C). As presented in Fig. 4(g), the first discharge capacity of Ge/3DPG-2 at 0.5 C is 1091 mAh g−1, and remains a high discharge capacity of 931 mAh g−1 after 250 cycles, corresponding to a decent capacity retention of 85.3%. The initial discharge capacities of Ge, Ge/3DPG-1 and Ge/3DPG-3 at 0.5 C are listed in Table S4. The capacity retention of Ge/3DPG-2 (85.3%) is higher than that of Ge (30.8%), Ge/3DPG-1 (76.3%) and Ge/3DPG-3 (71.2%), showing superior long-term cycle stability of Ge/3DPG-2. The lower capacity retention of Ge/3DPG-1 than Ge/3DPG-2 is probably because the overloading of RGO makes the RGO nanosheets thicker and increases the formation of SEI film during the continuous discharge/charge process, which consumes more lithium ions and causes the decrease of its capacity retention [54,55]. In addition, for the Ge/3DPG-3 electrode, too lower rGO content cannot effectively buffer the volume expansion and maintain the structural integrity of the electrode, thus resulting in its lower capacity retention. It is worth mentioning that the cycling performance and rate capability of the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode are comparable or even superior to those of the previously reported Ge-based anodes despite the relatively lower Ge content of Ge/3DPG-2 (Table S5). To understand the crucial relationship between the electrochemical lithium storage reactions and the cycling behavior of the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode and compare with Ge-2, we plotted the differential capacity curves (Fig. 5 ) from the corresponding discharge–charge profiles (Fig. S7) at a current density of 0.2C. As shown in Fig. 5(a), the differential capacity plot (DCP) of the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode during the lithium insertion for the 4th cycle is similar to the forementioned CV curve in cathodic scanning, wherein several reversible reduction peaks are orderly labeled as R1, R2, R3, and R4. From the 4th cycles onwards, the position and/or intensity of these cathodic peaks have an obvious change. The R1 peak at ca. 0.64 V, possibly corresponding to the reduction of re-oxidized Ge during the charging process, gradually shifted to a higher potential, along with intensity broadening and further weakening, meaning that the reoxidation process of Ge can gradually diminish with cycling [56]. On the contrary, the other three cathodic peaks at ca. 0.51 (R2), 0.37 (R3), and 0.18 V (R4), corresponding to the formation of Li x Ge alloys, increase in intensity with cycling. This phenomenon suggests that the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode exhibits a gradually improved lithiation process due to a slightly changed pathway of lithium insertion [56]. Specifically, the sharp R4 peak correlated with the generation of the high-capacity c-Li15Ge4 phase is evidently enhanced, revealing the stable formation of more c-Li15Ge4 at the end of the full lithiation, thus leading to the high reversible Li+ storage of the electrode [40]. The formation of more c-Li15Ge4 during the discharging process can be attributed to the synergistic effect of the nanosized Ge particles and the 3D conductive graphene framework. The similar change also occurred in the DCPs from the charge profiles. During the Li+ extraction process, the multiple anodic peaks, associated with the de-lithiation of lithium alloys (O1, O2, and O3) and the re-oxidation of a-Ge (O4), are visible in the DCP for the 4th cycle, as depicted in Fig. 5(b). The broad peak (O1) occurred near 0.41 V is owing to the de-lithiation of the amorphous Li-Ge phase, and gradually decreases as cycling increases, along with the stepwise decline of another de-lithiation peak (O3) at ca. 0.64 V. Instead, an intense and sharp anodic peak (O2), corresponding to the de-lithiation of c-Li15Ge4, shifts from ca. 0.46 to 0.49 V, accompanied by increasing peak intensity. The change trend of these anodic peaks implies that more of the stabilized c-Li15Ge4 phase was formed during repeated electrochemical lithiation processes due to a crystalline-amorphous phase transition of the lithium alloy [40,57,58]. This is in close agreement with the observation made in the DCPs for the discharging process. In addition, the weak and broad anodic peak (O4), associated with the re-oxidation of a-Ge, appears at ca. 1.10 V, revealing the reversibility of the conversion reaction of Li2O/Ge, which avoided the serious capacity loss of the electrode in the initial cycles [42]. Notably, the reoxidation peak (O4) associated with the conversion reaction gradually weaken in the subsequent cycles, suggesting the gradual decrease of the conversion of Li2O as well as the re-oxidation of Ge. Specifically, the Li2O formed during the discharging process can be only partially decomposed in the following charging process, accompanied by the loss of a part of lithium, which can result in the decline of the amount of Li2O involved in the subsequent conversion reaction, thus leading to the reduction of the conversion reaction as the cycling proceeds. Although the gradual diminishment of the reoxidation peak could cause some loss of capacity with increasing cycle number, the reversible transformation of the high capacity c-Li15Ge4 and a-Ge phases during repeated lithiation/de-lithiation can greatly guarantee the high capacity and capacity retention of the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode. The above result clearly explains that the capacity of the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode has a slight drop in the initial several cycles, but keeps almost stable in subsequent cycles. For the Ge-2 anode, the similar differential capacity plots (Fig. 5c and d) to that of Ge/3DPG-2 can be seen in the 4th cycle, including multiple lithium insertion/extraction peaks as well as the re-oxidation peak of a-Ge. However, from the 4th cycle onwards, the number and intensity of several lithiation peaks between 0.01 and 0.70 V dramatically decrease, only retaining a small broad peak at ca. 0.38 V and a sharp peak near 0.18 V after 15 cycles. Concomitantly, the broad oxidation peak at ca. 0.36 V and a sharp peak at ca. 0.49 V associated with the delithiation of the c-Li15G4 phase gradually weaken with the increasing cycles, further indicative of the decreased reversibility of the Ge-2 electrode. Notably, the former retains relatively high peak intensity compared to the latter, suggesting that the formation of the crystalline c-Li15G4 product becomes difficult with cycling progress, and thus more of the fully lithiated active material exists as the lower capacity amorphous alloy. This result is consistent with the rapid capacity fading of the Ge-2 anode during repeated lithiation and delithiation cycles [40]. Thus, the above difference in the electrochemical lithium storage process of the Ge-2 and Ge/3DPG-2 electrodes can expressly explain the different cycling behaviors of them. To further illuminate the crystal phase change of the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode, we assembled an in-situ XRD cell by directly coating the slurry on the Be foil [59]. The in-situ XRD results and corresponding voltage profile of the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode during the first galvanostatic electrochemical cycle are plotted in Fig. 6 (a). The peaks marked with clubs belong to the background, including the Be window and other components in the electrode. During the initial discharge stage, the intensity of the characteristic peaks at 27.3°, 45.3°, and 53.7°, corresponding to the (111), (220), and (311) planes of diamond cubic Ge, respectively, gradually decreases as the potential drops, corresponding to the conversion of crystalline Ge into amorphous Ge and amorphous Li x Ge. When the potential reaches ca. 0.15 V, a new diffraction peak appears at 41.4°, corresponding to poorly crystallized/amorphous lithiated states, possibly Li7Ge2 (or Li7Ge3) [60]. At the lower potentials (ca. 0.05 V), more peaks appear at 26.1°, 39.2°, and 42.8°, which can be attributed to Li15Ge4 [JCPDS No. 89–2584] [60–62]. In the followed process of lithium extraction, the intensities of c-Li15Ge4 and Li7Ge2 (or Li7Ge3) peaks decrease and completely disappear at ∼0.80 V. Moreover, no diffraction peaks associated with the (111), (220), and (311) planes of crystalline Ge can be found near the end of the first delithiation cycle, confirming the amorphization of c-Ge into a-Ge. This phase transformation of c-Ge into a-Ge during the initial discharge/charge process is further confirmed by ex-situ XRD results in Fig. S11. In addition, the diffraction peaks assigned to Li2CO3 and LiOH can be detected by ex-situ XRD (Fig. S11) during the first discharging process, and still existed in the subsequent process of lithium extraction, which could be mainly attributed to the formation of the stable SEI film [63]. The stable SEI film is beneficial to ensure the structural integrity of the electrode and improve the long-term cycle stability. It is also noteworthy that no characteristic peak of Li2O can be observed in in-situ or ex-situ XRD results during the initial discharging process, one can envision the Li2O matrix derived from the lithiation of native oxide at the Ge grain boundaries is an amorphous phase [63]. To further understand the rate capability of the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode and account for the kinetics difference between pure Ge and Ge/3DPG-2, the CV measurement was carried out under various sweep rates. Fig. 6(b) shows the CV curves of the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode at different scanning speeds from 0.2 to 1.0 mV s−1, in which two pairs of distinct reduction–oxidation peaks can be utilized to quantify the ratios of capacitive contribution and diffusion-controlled contribution in Ge/3DPG-2. As shown in Fig. S12(a), the CV curves of the Ge-2 electrode at different scan rates maintain almost the same shape, and the oxidation and reduction peaks show a slightly increasing intensity with the increase of scan rate, which is similar to the case of the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode (Fig. 6b). Based on the relationship between the measured peak current (i) and scanning speeds (v) (i = av b), the b value can be calculated by the linear relation between log (v) and log (i). Here, a and b are both adjustable empirical parameters, especially that the b value can reflect the lithium storage behavior. Generally, the b value is between 0.5 and 1.0, where 0.5 features a full diffusion-controlled process, while 1.0 indicates an ideal capacitive behavior. From the slopes of the log(v) ∼ log(i) plots (Fig. 6c), the b values for the four peaks of the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode were calculated to be 0.79 (peak 1), 0.90 (peak 2), 0.85 (peak 3), and 0.68 (peak 4), respectively, which are also higher than those for the Ge-2 electrode (Fig. S12b) at identical peak positions. The result demonstrates that Ge/3DPG-2 has a faster kinetic dominated by the capacitance-controlled behavior during the lithium storage process [64–66]. The ratios of the capacitive contribution in the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode can be evaluated by separating the current response i at a fixed voltage V into the capacitance-controlled fraction (k 1 v) and diffusion-controlled portion (k 2 v 1/2), according to the equation: i (V) = k 1 v + k 2 v 1/2 [67–69]. As shown in Fig. 6(d), compared with the total capacity, the capacitive contribution (blue area) for Ge/3DPG-2 is outstanding and can be up to 60% at a scan rate of 0.6 mV s−1. At the other scanning rates, the corresponding capacitance-controlled contribution is 48% (0.2 mV s−1), 54% (0.4 mV s−1), 64% (0.8 mV s−1), and 67% (1.0 mV s−1), and thus the ratio increases with the increasing sweep rate (Fig. 6e). It is clearly observed that the capacitive contribution ratio of Ge/3DPG-2 is also higher than that of pure Ge at each scan rate. The result confirms that the capacitance-controlled process plays a dominating role in the lithium storage of the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode, probably because the combination of nano-scale Ge and RGO with a unique 3D porous structure can provide rich surface/interfaces to capture more Li+ by surface absorption or redox reaction, which eventually improves the surface capacitive contribution in Ge/3DPG-2 [70]. Thus, with the help of the enhanced surface-controlled kinetics, the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode exhibits excellent rate properties. Such excellent pseudo-capacitive storage behavior for the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode might be related to the structural features with a three-dimensional porous hybrid structure composed of Ge nanoparticles and 3D graphene frameworks [71]. To further clarify the effect of the ratio of Ge to RGO on the electrochemical performance of the composite electrodes, the morphological and swelling variations of the electrodes before cycling and after cycling were studied by SEM. Obviously, the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode after 100 cycles at 0.2C keeps its initial appearance, without serious cracking and pulverization happening on its surface (insets of Fig. 7 a and c). Meanwhile, after cycling, the surface of the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode became smooth, and many large gaps like ravines became small and even disappeared (Fig. 7a and c), which can be ascribed to the formation of a stable SEI film on the surface of active materials. After 100 cycles, the electrode of Ge/3DPG-1 with a higher RGO content also showed similar changes to Ge/3DPG-2 (Fig. S13a), while the Ge/3DPG-3 electrode with the lower RGO content occurred cracking and pulverization after 100 cycles (Fig. S13d), possibly because its lower RGO content cannot efficiently ease the huge volume change of Ge during cycling. As expected, without the protection of RGO, the surface of the cycled Ge-2 electrode generated lots of cracks, and even some of the active materials fell off from the copper foil (Fig. S13g). Moreover, the thickness of the cycled Ge/3DPG-1 and Ge/3DPG-2 electrodes increased from 7.0 and 8.2 to 11.3 and 13.0 μm, respectively, with a close swelling rate of 61.4% (Ge/3DPG-1) and 58.5% (Ge/3DPG-2), which aremuch smaller than 90.0% of Ge/3DPG-3 (Fig. 7b and d, and Fig. S13b, c, e, and f). However, compared to these Ge/3DPG composite electrodes, the cycled Ge-2 electrode shows the largest swelling rate of 210.2% (Fig. S13h and i), which can seriously damage the electrical contact between active materials and the current collector, thus causing rapid capacity fading. It’s worth noting that the thickness of Ge/3DPG-2 increased from 8.0 to 22.6 μm after 250 cycles at a relatively larger current density of 0.5C, but the active material can still maintain good electrical contact with the current collector (Cu foil) (Fig. 7e and f), demonstrating that the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode possesses good structural stability upon cycling. The outstanding cycling stability and reversibility of the Ge/3DPG-2 electrode can benefit from the synergistic effect of Ge nanoparticles and RGO sheets, as well as the 3D interconnected porous structure, which can greatly buffer the volume variation at the continuous Li-insertion/extraction process to achieve good preservation of the electrode structure. Based on the aforementioned electrochemical lithium storage performance of as-prepared electrodes together with the corresponding analyses of the reaction mechanism and kinetics, crystal structure, and microstructure during cycling, a representative schematic diagram of the lithium alloying/de-alloying with the Ge/3DPG electrode is depicted to clearly and visually understand its excellent electrochemical performance (Fig. 7g). A partially reversible conversion reaction occurred upon the initial lithiation, followed by the reversible alloying reaction to form different lithium alloys, specifically the full-lithiation crystalline phase (c-Li15Ge4) with high capacity. In the reverse process, the multistep dealloying of Li-Ge phases to a-Ge is accompanied by the partial re-oxidation of a-Ge to germanium oxide. In subsequent cycles, the reversible Li+ storage of the Ge/3DPG electrode is substantially attributed to the reversible lithium reactions with a-Ge, as well as the partially reversible conversion reaction of Li2O/Ge. During cycling, the nano-sized Ge has a relatively smaller volume variation than the bulk, which could efficiently ensure good electrical contact with the conductive carbon matrix, improving the structural integrity of the electrode. On the other hand, the conductive 3D porous graphene frameworks have unique 3D interconnected channels, which can not only facilitate the permeation of the electrolyte and the transfer of electrons and ions, but also buffer the volume change of Ge during cycling, improving the long cycle lifespan of the electrode [12]. Furthermore, the coexistence of Ge and 3DPG can greatly improve the reversibility of the conversion reaction between lithia and germanium, in particular, the metallic Ge nanoparticles play a catalytic role in facilitating the decomposition of Li2O along with the regeneration of germania over initial tens of cycles [12,42]. Therefore, the enhanced electrochemical performance of the Ge/3DPG electrode benefits from its unique structural design and the synergy between nanoscale active materials (Ge) and 3D porous graphene frameworks. To further evaluate the potential practical application of Ge/3DPG-2 as an anode in LIBs, we assembled a full battery by pairing Ge/3DPG-2 anode with LiFePO4 cathode. Fig. 8 (a) shows the discharge/charge curves of the Ge/3DPG-2//LiFePO4 full battery for the initial five cycles at 0.1C (1C = 170 mA g−1). The primary discharge voltage platform for the full cell is at around 2.8 V, which corresponds to the potential gap between the discharge voltage platform for LFP cathodes (≈ 3.3 V) and that for the anodes (≈ 0.5 V) [15]. The initial discharge and charge capacities are 156 and 147 mAh g−1, respectively, corresponding to an ICE of 94%, and the reversible capacity after the initial five cycles can reach up to 149 mAh g−1. Even after 50 cycles under a relatively big current density of 0.5C, the discharge capacity of the full cell still delivers 115 mAh g−1, with the capacity retention of 83%, showing a decent cycling stability (Fig. 8b). The Ge/3DPG-2//LiFePO4 full battery exhibits reversible capacities of 149, 132, 115, 103, 90, 80 and 63 mAh g−1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 3 and 5C, respectively (Fig. 8c and d). When the rate returns to 0.2C, the capacity can recover to 127 mAh g−1. These results further reveal that Ge/3DPG-2 possesses great potential in practical application. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have successfully synthesized Ge/3DPG composites with Ge nanoparticles anchored on 3D interconnected porous graphene frameworks using a simple hard template-assisted in-situ reduction method. The unique 3D interconnected porous graphene framework can not only improve the electronic conductivity and enhance ions diffusion kinetics, but also serve as a buffering matrix to effectively alleviate a huge volume variation of Ge during repeated lithiation/de-lithiation processes and promote the reversible utilization of Li2O. Furthermore, the Ge nanoparticles in close conjunction with 3DPG through the chemical bond (Ge-C) can effectively strengthen the structural integrity of materials during cycling. After optimizing the RGO content, the obtained Ge/3DPG-2 composite exhibits a capacitance-controlled lithium storage performance, including the high reversible specific capacity, outstanding rate capability, and a good long cycle lifespan. Thus, the Ge/3DPG-2 composite is a promising candidate for high-performance LIB anodes. Moreover, its rational design provides inspiration for the preparation of various metal nanoparticles decorated on 3D porous graphene frameworks, which could be widely used in energy storage, catalysis and other fields. coredata.dc:description: Germanium (Ge), an alloy-type anode material for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), possesses many advantages such as high theoretical capacity and decent electrical conductivity. Nevertheless, its application is restricted by tremendous volume variation and tardy reaction kinetic during discharge/charge process. In this paper, the Ge/3DPG composites with Ge nanoparticles uniformly dispersed in 3D interconnected porous graphene (3DPG) skeleton are successfully prepared using a template-assisted in-situ reduction method. The unique 3D interconnected porous graphene can not only enhance the electronic conductivity and reaction kinetics of the materials, but also provide sufficient buffer space to effectively mitigate the volume expansion during cycling and strengthen the structural integrity. Moreover, the small-sized Ge nanoparticles in close conjunction with the 3D graphene can boost the surface-controlled reaction of the electrode, which contributes to a fast charge–discharge rate capability. The Ge/3DPG composite with optimized Ge/graphene mass ratio delivers high reversible specific capacity (1102 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.2 C), outstanding rate capability (494 mAh g−1 at 5 C), and admirable cycling stability (85.3% of capacity retention after 250 cycles at 0.5 C). This work provides a significant inspiration for the design and fabrication of advanced Ge-based anode materials for next-generation high-performance LIBs.
